dublinCore.dc:title: 114 HR 1269 IH: Rafael Ramos and Wenjian Liu National Blue Alert Act of 2015
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Reichert (for himself, Mr. Pascrell, Mr. King of New York, and Mr. Pierluisi) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To encourage, enhance, and integrate Blue Alert plans throughout the United States in order to disseminate information when a law enforcement officer is seriously injured or killed in the line of duty, is missing in connection with the officer’s official duties, or an imminent and credible threat that an individual intends to cause the serious injury or death of a law enforcement officer is received, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Rafael Ramos and Wenjian Liu National Blue Alert Act of 2015.

paragraph.text: The term Coordinator means the Blue Alert Coordinator of the Department of Justice designated under section 4(a).
The term Blue Alert means information sent through the network relating to—

subparagraph.text: the serious injury or death of a law enforcement officer in the line of duty;
an officer who is missing in connection with the officer’s official duties; or
an imminent and credible threat that an individual intends to cause the serious injury or death of a law enforcement officer.

paragraph.text: The term Blue Alert plan means the plan of a State, unit of local government, or Federal agency participating in the network for the dissemination of information received as a Blue Alert.
The term law enforcement officer shall have the same meaning as in section 1204 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 (42 U.S.C. 3796b).
The term network means the Blue Alert communications network established by the Attorney General under section 3.
The term State means each of the 50 States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands.

section.text: The Attorney General shall establish a national Blue Alert communications network within the Department of Justice to issue Blue Alerts through the initiation, facilitation, and promotion of Blue Alert plans, in coordination with States, units of local government, law enforcement agencies, and other appropriate entities.

subsection.text: The Attorney General shall assign an existing officer of the Department of Justice to act as the national coordinator of the Blue Alert communications network.

paragraph.text: provide assistance to States and units of local government that are using Blue Alert plans;

establish voluntary guidelines for States and units of local government to use in developing Blue Alert plans that will promote compatible and integrated Blue Alert plans throughout the United States, including—

subparagraph.text: a list of the resources necessary to establish a Blue Alert plan;
criteria for evaluating whether a situation warrants issuing a Blue Alert;
guidelines to protect the privacy, dignity, independence, and autonomy of any law enforcement officer who may be the subject of a Blue Alert and the family of the law enforcement officer;
guidelines that a Blue Alert should only be issued with respect to a law enforcement officer if—

clause.text: the law enforcement agency involved—

item.text: the death or serious injury of the law enforcement officer; or
the attack on the law enforcement officer and that there is an indication of the death or serious injury of the officer; or

subclause.text: concludes that the law enforcement officer is missing in connection with the officer’s official duties;

clause.text: there is an indication of serious injury to or death of the law enforcement officer;
the suspect involved has not been apprehended; and
there is sufficient descriptive information of the suspect involved and any relevant vehicle and tag numbers;

subparagraph.text: guidelines that a Blue Alert should only be issued with respect to a threat to cause death or serious injury to a law enforcement officer if—

clause.text: a law enforcement agency involved confirms that the threat is imminent and credible;
at the time of receipt of the threat, the suspect is wanted by a law enforcement agency;
the suspect involved has not been apprehended; and
there is sufficient descriptive information of the suspect involved and any relevant vehicle and tag numbers;

subparagraph.text: guidelines—

clause.text: that information should be provided to the National Crime Information Center database operated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation under section 534 of title 28, United States Code, and any relevant crime information repository of the State involved, relating to—

subclause.text: a law enforcement officer who is seriously injured or killed in the line of duty; or
an imminent and credible threat to cause the serious injury or death of a law enforcement officer;

clause.text: that a Blue Alert should, to the maximum extent practicable (as determined by the Coordinator in consultation with law enforcement agencies of States and units of local governments), be limited to the geographic areas most likely to facilitate the apprehension of the suspect involved or which the suspect could reasonably reach, which should not be limited to State lines;
for law enforcement agencies of States or units of local government to develop plans to communicate information to neighboring States to provide for seamless communication of a Blue Alert; and
providing that a Blue Alert should be suspended when the suspect involved is apprehended or when the law enforcement agency involved determines that the Blue Alert is no longer effective; and

subparagraph.text: guidelines for—

clause.text: the issuance of Blue Alerts through the network; and
the extent of the dissemination of alerts issued through the network;

paragraph.text: develop protocols for efforts to apprehend suspects that address activities during the period beginning at the time of the initial notification of a law enforcement agency that a suspect has not been apprehended and ending at the time of apprehension of a suspect or when the law enforcement agency involved determines that the Blue Alert is no longer effective, including protocols regulating—

subparagraph.text: the use of public safety communications;
command center operations; and
incident review, evaluation, debriefing, and public information procedures;

paragraph.text: work with States to ensure appropriate regional coordination of various elements of the network;

establish an advisory group to assist States, units of local government, law enforcement agencies, and other entities involved in the network with initiating, facilitating, and promoting Blue Alert plans, which shall include—

subparagraph.text: to the maximum extent practicable, representation from the various geographic regions of the United States; and
members who are—

clause.text: representatives of a law enforcement organization representing rank-and-file officers;
representatives of other law enforcement agencies and public safety communications;
broadcasters, first responders, dispatchers, and radio station personnel; and
representatives of any other individuals or organizations that the Coordinator determines are necessary to the success of the network;

paragraph.text: act as the nationwide point of contact for—

subparagraph.text: the development of the network; and
regional coordination of Blue Alerts through the network; and
what procedures and practices are in use for notifying law enforcement and the public when—

clause.text: a law enforcement officer is killed or seriously injured in the line of duty;
a law enforcement officer is missing in connection with the officer’s official duties; and
an imminent and credible threat to kill or seriously injure a law enforcement officer is received; and

subparagraph.text: which of the procedures and practices are effective and that do not require the expenditure of additional resources to implement.

paragraph.text: The guidelines established under subsection (b)(2), protocols developed under subsection (b)(3), and other programs established under subsection (b), shall not be mandatory.

The guidelines established under subsection (b)(2) shall, to the maximum extent practicable (as determined by the Coordinator in consultation with law enforcement agencies of States and units of local government), provide that appropriate information relating to a Blue Alert is disseminated to the appropriate officials of law enforcement agencies, public health agencies, and other agencies.
The guidelines established under subsection (b) shall—

subparagraph.text: provide mechanisms that ensure that Blue Alerts comply with all applicable Federal, State, and local privacy laws and regulations; and

include standards that specifically provide for the protection of the civil liberties, including the privacy, of law enforcement officers who are seriously injured or killed in the line of duty, are missing in connection with their official duties, or who are threatened with death or serious injury, and of the families of the officers.

subsection.text: The Coordinator shall cooperate with the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of Transportation, the Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, and appropriate offices of the Department of Justice in carrying out activities under this Act.

paragraph.text: perform any official travel for the sole purpose of carrying out the duties of the Coordinator;
lobby any officer of a State regarding the funding or implementation of a Blue Alert plan; or
host a conference focused solely on the Blue Alert program that requires the expenditure of Federal funds.

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, and annually thereafter, the Coordinator shall submit to Congress a report on the activities of the Coordinator and the effectiveness and status of the Blue Alert plans that are in effect or being developed.
